Title: Satoshi's Bitcoin Whitepaper Turns 17: From Cypherpunk Rebellion to Wall Street Staple
URL: https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2025/11/01/satoshi-s-bitcoin-whitepaper-turns-17-from-cypherpunk-rebellion-to-wall-street-staple
Time Published: 2025-11-01T14:00:00Z
Full Content:
The Bitcoin whitepaper, A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System, published by the mysterious and pseudonymous Satoshi Nakamoto, turned seventeen years old yesterday. Released on Oct. 31, 2008, amid the global financial crisis, the nine-page document laid the foundation for what would become the world‚Äôs first cryptocurrency. The whitepaper outlined a vision for a decentralized, peer-to-peer financial system built on cryptographic proof rather than trust in third-party intermediaries. Its goal was to eliminate the problem of double-spending and enable online transactions without relying on banks or other trusted third parties. ‚ÄúWe have proposed a system for electronic transactions without relying on trust,‚Äù Satoshi wrote. Seventeen years later, Bitcoin‚Äôs influence has reached far beyond the cypherpunk forums where it began. The anniversary comes as U.S. spot bitcoin ETFs in less than two years of existence have experienced unprecedented success, seeing total net inflow of over $62 billion and total net assets exceeding $150 billion, according to SoSoValue data. But Bitcoin‚Äôs mainstream acceptance extends beyond Wall Street. It has now entered the highest levels of government, including the White House under the current U.S. administration. Some of Bitcoin‚Äôs most outspoken critics have become its biggest advocates. In 2021, former President Donald Trump dismissed Bitcoin as a ‚Äúscam against the dollar.‚Äù Yet by the 2024 presidential election, he was urging supporters to ‚Äúnever sell your bitcoin‚Äù and went on to sign an executive order establishing a bitcoin strategic reserve. Larry Fink, CEO of BlackRock the world‚Äôs largest asset manager once called Bitcoin an ‚Äúindex of money laundering.‚Äù Today, he champions it as one of his firm‚Äôs most successful ETF products and views it as a hedge against sovereign debt instability.Likewise, Michael Saylor, the outspoken CEO of Strategy, has become one of Bitcoin‚Äôs most persistent evangelists, continuing to accumulate BTC through stock and debt offerings. Saylor himself began as a skeptic, once declaring, ‚ÄúBitcoin‚Äôs days are numbered. It seems like just a matter of time before it suffers the same fate as online gambling.‚Äù The last major holdout among prominent financial figures remains JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, who continues to voice doubts about Bitcoin‚Äôs value and sustainability. His bank though, has heartily moved into the sector, including recently allowing clients to pledge bitcoin as collateral. The financialization of bitcoin through ETFs and corporate treasury adoption has drawn comparisons to the mortgage securitization boom of the 1970s an era that saw asset prices soar to new heights. Yet this evolution has not pleased everyone. Many early Bitcoin believers argue that that its very ethos, a form of money outside the control of the state, has been diluted by institutional adoption. For the cypherpunk movement that birthed Bitcoin, the system‚Äôs embrace by Wall Street and Washington feels like a paradox: a rebellion absorbed by the establishment it once sought to disrupt. On an annual basis, the average transaction fee per bitcoin block has fallen to its lowest level since 2010, raising concerns about the network‚Äôs long-term sustainability. Low fees, while attractive for users, reduce incentives for miners who secure the network, especially as block rewards continue to halve every four years. Originally envisioned as a peer-to-peer electronic cash system, Bitcoin has increasingly been overshadowed by the ‚Äústore of value‚Äù narrative. "Never sell your bitcoin," is a common refrain from Michael Saylor to the Trump family and many voices in between. At the same time, controversy continues within the developer community particularly between Bitcoin Core and Bitcoin Knots over whether the network should allow non-monetary data like Ordinals or enforce stricter rules to block it. Some see such restrictions as necessary to preserve the network‚Äôs integrity, while others view them as a form of censorship that alters bitcoin‚Äôs open and permissionless nature. Beyond internal debates, the looming question of quantum computing also poses an unresolved risk. The potential for future quantum machines to break existing cryptographic standards could threaten Bitcoin‚Äôs security, with no definitive solution in place yet. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no doubt that Bitcoin has arrived, accepted by Wall Street, and its sustained period above $100,000 confirms that," said Bitcoin OG Nicholas Gregory recently. "Its transition from peer-to-peer cash to a store of value is evident," he continued. "It remains to be seen where it goes long-term. I, for one, think the narrative of it as a medium of exchange is key to its enduring place, along with solutions to the quantum threat." More For You OwlTing: Stablecoin Infrastructure for the Future Stablecoin payment volumes have grown to $19.4B year-to-date in 2025. OwlTing aims to capture this market by developing payment infrastructure that processes transactions in seconds for fractions of a cent. More For You Analyst Says Ethereum Is the Best Ecosystem and Ether Is Poised to Top $5,000 Ether rose on heavier trading, then slipped after an upper-band rejection, leaving a tighter range and a clear set of checkpoints above and below. What to know: Disclosure & Polices: CoinDesk is an award-winning media outlet that covers the cryptocurrency industry. Its journalists abide by a strict set of editorial policies. CoinDesk has adopted a set of principles aimed at ensuring the integrity, editorial independence and freedom from bias of its publications. CoinDesk is part of Bullish (NYSE:BLSH), an institutionally focused global digital asset platform that provides market infrastructure and information services. Bullish owns and invests in digital asset businesses and digital assets and CoinDesk employees, including journalists, may receive Bullish equity-based compensation.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: AI Blamed for Tens of Thousands of White Collar Layoffs
URL: http://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/ai-white-collar-layoffs
Time Published: 2025-11-01T13:45:00Z
Full Content:
By Rae Witte Published Nov 1, 2025 9:45 AM EDT There‚Äôs no question that the job market is a mess. According to Labor Department data, nearly two million Americans have been without a job for 27 weeks or more, the highest figure since 2022. And it‚Äôs hitting white collar jobs hard: this week alone, Amazon cut its corporate workforce by 14,000 jobs, UPS cut 34,000 operational workforce positions, and Target and Paramount axed 1,800 and 1,000 jobs, respectively. Many are blaming those cuts on AI. Everyone from Senator Bernie Sanders to Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell is wringing their hands about the tech‚Äôs effect on employment. Mike Hoffman, CEO of growth advisory firm SBI, told the Wall Street Journal that productivity surged when he cut his software development team by 80 percent. And Meta just culled 600 employees from the AI Superintelligence lab ‚Äî after dropping billions to beef up the team ‚Äî and blamed advancements in automation. Others aren‚Äôt so sure. New research found that even the world‚Äôs strongest AI agents struggled to perform the vast majority of tasks that companies currently lean on independent contractors for. According to a recent study from MIT, 95 percent of companies that adopt AI see zero meaningful revenue growth. Some companies are finding they‚Äôre forced to hire contractors to fix AI‚Äôs mistakes, or even to re-hire staff they terminated in favor of the tech. It all raises an interesting counter-possibility: maybe instead of AI actually replacing human-level intellectual labor, bosses are running with the narrative that it‚Äôs ready to replace human workers to justify layoffs ‚Äî when what‚Äôs really happening is they‚Äôre offloading work onto a smaller human workforce, or forcing their overburdened remaining employees to produce lower quality results. The reality is that there are other major headwinds dragging down the economy. The US is now in a perpetual state of political uncertainty that has directly impacted many employers. President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs were announced, postponed, instated, rolled back, rinsed and repeated; his restrictive immigration policies and deportations are shrinking the workforce and increasing labor costs; cutting the $7,500 consumer incentive for electric vehicles is forcing layoffs in that sector. AI is a flashy scapegoat for mounting white collar layoffs, in other words, and if it keeps improving, it may eventually pose a real threat to jobs. But for now, it feels more like a bogeyman to rationalize short-term cost cutting ‚Äî and any companies that indulge in it may find that they‚Äôre undermining their reputation and institutional knowledge for years to come. More on the job market: Fed Boss Concerned About AI‚Äôs Effect on Job Market By Joe Wilkins By Victor Tangermann By Frank Landymore By Joe Wilkins By Joe Wilkins By Joe Wilkins By Joe Wilkins By Frank Landymore By Joe Wilkins By Joe Wilkins By Sharon Adarlo By Joe Wilkins By Joe Wilkins Disclaimer(s) Articles may contain affiliate links which enable us to share in the revenue of any purchases made. Title: The 10 best and 10 worst states for finding a job right now
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/best-worst-states-for-jobs-2025
Time Published: 2025-11-01T13:02:01Z
Full Content:
Every time Alcynna publishes a story, you‚Äôll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insider‚Äôs Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. If you're one of the millions of unemployed Americans looking for work right now, it's clear the job market is tough. Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that in August, the number of job seekers outpaced available openings in the US for the first time since April 2021. The shift comes amid a wave of layoffs this year across major employers, including Amazon, Meta, and GM. For many out-of-work Americans, it's easy to feel discouraged ‚Äî but there's still hope. WalletHub has ranked the best and worst cities in the US for job hunters, showing where your odds might be strongest and weakest. To find out where you'll have the best chance at landing, keeping, and actually enjoying a job, WalletHub compared all 50 states using 34 metrics that reflect job-market strength and economic health. These include factors such as employment growth, median annual income, average commute time, job security, and even the likelihood that artificial intelligence could take your job in the future. WalletHub found that many of the best states for jobs are clustered in New England, the Upper Midwest, and the Great Plains, with Texas being the lone Southern state. Despite their regional and industry differences, from tech in Massachusetts to agriculture in the Dakotas, these states share common strengths: low unemployment, solid job growth, and business-friendly environments. "The best states for jobs make it easier for residents to find and retain jobs, and employers in these states also offer very competitive compensation and benefits," said WalletHub analyst Chip Lupo. These are the 10 best and 10 worst states for job prospects, according to WalletHub. Title: US stock market November 2025 forecast: Will Wall Street‚Äôs strongest month of the year deliver another surprise rally? 3 big shifts to note

Title: YouTube CEO emphasizes AI as the next technological frontier
URL: https://www.uxpin.com/studio/blog/youtube-ceo-emphasizes-ai-technological-frontier/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T11:11:20Z
Full Content:
YouTube is embarking on a transformative journey into artificial intelligence (AI), as CEO Neal Mohan outlined plans to position the platform at the forefront of this technological shift. In a memo to employees earlier in October, Mohan declared, "the next frontier for YouTube is AI", unveiling a significant reorganization of the company‚Äôs product and engineering divisions, which will take effect on November 5, 2025. To better align YouTube with its AI-driven ambitions, the company will restructure its operations into three primary product organizations, all reporting directly to Mohan. Johanna Voolich will oversee Viewer Products, managing areas such as Search and Discovery, the Living Room app, infrastructure, and Trust and Safety. Meanwhile, the Creator and Community Products group, temporarily under Voolich‚Äôs leadership, will focus on YouTube Shorts, Live, and expanding generative AI tools to assist creators. Christian Oestlien will lead the Subscription Products division, handling YouTube Premium, Music, TV, and other over-the-top initiatives. The company is also making internal changes to improve efficiency and collaboration. The UX organization, led by JT, will integrate with Scott‚Äôs engineering team to streamline processes. Similarly, the Shopping group, under Travis‚Äôs leadership, will continue to report to Scott. Mohan emphasized that these adjustments aim to strengthen decision-making, enhance accountability, and ensure high-growth areas receive the necessary focus and investment. As part of the restructuring, YouTube introduced a voluntary exit program for U.S.-based employees within Mohan‚Äôs direct reporting organization. The program offers eligible employees the option to leave the company with a severance package, although the precise number of eligible employees remains undisclosed. A YouTube spokesperson clarified that the program is voluntary and does not involve layoffs or role eliminations. Details of the program are being communicated individually to those eligible. Mohan has been vocal about AI‚Äôs potential to transform YouTube‚Äôs platform and services. In an interview with The Hollywood Reporter, he stated, "AI in service of human creativity" is a central focus for the company. He explained how AI can enable creators to generate ideas, develop visuals, and enhance video production more efficiently. "I do think creation is an area where AI will help enormously by making the process easier, faster, and more powerful", Mohan added. The new Creator and Community Products organization will lead the development of these AI-powered tools. This commitment to AI mirrors broader trends in the tech industry. Major companies like Amazon, Meta, Microsoft, and Google‚Äôs DeepMind also recently announced significant organizational changes to integrate AI into their operations. However, unlike many of these companies, YouTube‚Äôs approach does not involve layoffs, instead opting for voluntary departures to adjust its structure. The reorganization comes at a time of robust financial performance for YouTube‚Äôs parent company, Alphabet. The company recently reported its first-ever quarter with revenue exceeding $100 billion, with net income rising 33 percent year-over-year. YouTube contributed significantly to this growth, generating $10.26 billion in ad revenue during the third quarter of 2025, a 15 percent increase from the previous year and ahead of Wall Street expectations. Acknowledging the platform‚Äôs success, Mohan highlighted YouTube‚Äôs evolution. The platform has paid more than $100 billion to its creators, maintained its position as the leading streaming service in the United States for over two years, and grown its user base to 125 million YouTube Premium and Music subscribers, along with 8 million YouTube TV subscribers. Despite this growth, Mohan noted that the core leadership structure "has not evolved in a decade", necessitating the reorganization to better align with the platform‚Äôs current scale and complexity. In his memo to employees, Mohan expressed optimism about YouTube‚Äôs trajectory. "It‚Äôs an incredibly exciting time at YouTube, and many opportunities and challenges lie ahead", he wrote. "Looking to the future, the next frontier for YouTube is AI, which has the potential to transform every part of the platform." The changes, he noted, are designed to enable the company to "make the most of this opportunity" and ensure leadership teams are well-equipped to prioritize high-growth areas. As YouTube moves forward with its restructuring, its focus remains clear: leveraging AI to enhance both content creation and user experiences, signaling a new chapter of innovation for the world‚Äôs largest video platform. The changes will officially take effect on November 5, 2025, marking the beginning of what Mohan described as "an incredibly exciting time at YouTube." The Left Wins the Irish Presidential Election in a Landslide Counterpunch To give some background ‚Äì Catherine Connolly is an ex Labour activist who left due (apparently) to internal fights within her local party. She was little known outside her constituency, although she seems to have been very well liked by other politicians including centrists ‚Äì her two political jobs ‚Äì Galway Mayor and Deputy Speaker for the parliament are both decided on open votes, which means a lot of the centre and right will have supported her. She was considered an outsider for the post, but as none of the left parties could agree on their own candidate, she became the de facto left candidate. She was also aided by the two centre right parties making an appalling mess of their campaign. She is a barrister and very good with both the public and on TV and won very easily. She has a long, consistent history of being on the general left of politics and in particular anti-war and anti-imperialism and pro-palestine (before it was fashionable, as they say). More recently, she seems to have become more nationalist on Irish unity (she keeps quiet on this as it‚Äôs the primary ideological issue dividing the left). The Presidential post is largely ceremonial and she will have little real power. It does have two significant political outcomes: 1. It will make it almost impossible for the current government to weaken Irish neutrality. She cannot block any attempt to join Nato or take part in military action, but she has the capacity to create a constitutional crisis over it, so no government would consider it worth the effort to try. It was never likely, but its pretty much an impossibility now for the next 7 years. 2. It greatly strengthens Sinn Fein (centre left/nationalist/republican). They initially couldn‚Äôt find a candidate that had any chance, so reluctantly backed her. But as they have by far the best electoral ground game, they became the de facto main partner in a loose alliance of left parties and the Greens. While that alliance lasts, it shows its possibilities in another election. But more crucially it has seriously weakened the current Prime Minister who despises Sinn Fein ‚Äì it seems very likely he will not make it to the election. His likely successor belongs to the republican radical wing of his party, one much more likely to join forces with Sinn Fein. So this could give SF two potential coalition partners after the next election ‚Äì a left wing/green alliance, or a centrist and left Republican one. They probably prefer the second option. She sounds very much like an Irish traditionalist in having Ireland be neutral and also pro-Palestinian out of principle. If she is there for the next seven years, then it may stabilize Irish politics and stop the idea I have heard of Ireland going into NATO so it can give all its military equipment to the Ukrainians and give Zelensky a coupla billion Euros. Forgive me as I have not been following Irish politics as closely as I used to, but is there really a movement among the Irish center-right to abandon neutrality and join NATO? The very idea seems so shockingly bad to me I could scarcely believe my eyes when I read your comment! No politician in Ireland who wants to get elected openly calls for it, but there is a lobby within the establishment who does want it (as this widely mocked article indicates). Michael Martin, the current PM, would try to move Ireland towards Nato if he could, but his party would never allow it. It would be a massive vote loser. The complication for Ireland is that even though it is not part of Nato, because of the lack of investment in defence over the years, the country has had little choice but to rely on UK/US and other European military help with various issues, from intercepting aircraft in Irelands aerospace to maritime rescue and heavy lift capacity for pulling citizens out of trouble around the world or in shoring up Irelands UN contingent (there has been an Irish Battalion in the Lebanon for nearly 3 decades now). For pragmatic reasons, Irelands small military accepts Nato standards for its equipment. So while neutrality is extremely popular with the electorate and the foreign establishment is split over this, no government aren‚Äôt actually willing to put in place a meaningful defence force. Interestingly, Sinn Fein has started calling for much more military spending. It is quite possible to envisage a situation where Ireland accepts membership of Nato as part of a deal for unification. ‚ÄúUS begins troop drawdown in Romania‚Äù Not just Romania but apparently Hungary, Bulgaria and Slovakia as well in December. I would imagine some panic in NATO over this as there might be the suspicion that Trump will eventually reduce US troop numbers until there is only a tripwire force left in Europe- https://www.kyivpost.com/post/63332 Not much profit to be had from only a tripwire force. They only need a skeleton force required for ISR the rest will be done with proxies. that is the European and West Asian plan. That is the impression that I got. That Trump & Co want Europe to field a strong military so that it can be its proxy force for that continent. The US would provide military equipment ‚Äì at marked up prices ‚Äì Europe would receive satellite data from the US but more to the point would have the US calling the shots for that European military like it does in places like South Korea. Maybe too like in South Korea, that there would be a US general put in charge of these European forces. maybe too the US would order deployment of that European force to places like Asia, maybe even Taiwan. A US general is, and has always been, the military head of NATO. This is no different, in practice, from US SK command structure. Would that include in combat as well? I know that is so for South Korea. Of course. SACEUR (who also has the US ‚Äúhat‚Äù of COMEUCOM) has operational command from SHAPE in Mons, BE. Many many of those banks were consolidated with buyouts into larger banking entities at the direction of the FDIC. If one wanted to further consolidate the banking sector and reduce the number of community and small regional banks, this is one way to do that, imo. It‚Äôs never the smaller banks that get bailed out. The smaller banks get eaten. And an aside about the private credit crisis that‚Äôs looming: The big banks beginning after the GFC essentially stopped loaning to small businesses, that created the environment for the expansion of existing and creation of new private credit outfits. Small businesses still needed operating capital loans, and when their longtime big bank stopped lending even though the small business owner had never missed a payment or been a problem, they naturally turned to local private credit outfits. If there‚Äôs a problem now in the private credit market, it‚Äôs a crisis the big banks created, imo. I would like to see a simple, easily understood metric used. Let us consider a mature P/E ratio as Nvidia ages to a mature company, free of hype. In a social media post criticizing what he called the ‚Äúmass slaughter‚Äù of Christians in the country, Trump wrote the United States would ‚Äúimmediately stop all aid and assistance to Nigeria‚Äù and warned the government there to ‚Äúmove fast.‚Äù I guess he learned from Trump 1.0 that you‚Äôre greatly applauded for using the US military aggressively, without foresight or forethought. ‚ÄúCoronavirus found in samples from 96% of flights‚Äù News that you can use. It means that instead of wondering the need for masks when boarding a flight, the answer is now a definite YES. Every flight is almost guaranteed to be infected. I never stopped wearing a mask in airports, on flights, public transit or medical settings of any kind. It‚Äôs never going away, and ‚Äúour betters‚Äù will never countenance any investment in indoor air quality. Your email address will not be published. Title: Amazon layoffs: Why did the tech giant send two text messages to their employees and asked them to call help desk? Check details

Time Published: 2025-11-01T10:18:01Z

Amazon is implementing significant job cuts, impacting approximately 14,000 corporate employees, despite robust quarterly profits. Some employees learned of their fate through an impersonal text-message blast. This strategic move, attributed to advancements in artificial intelligence and a shift in investment, aims to streamline operations and reduce bureaucracy. Affected employees will receive severance and support services as the tech giant navigates a changing landscape. Title: Amazon CEO says layoffs aren't about AI, as cuts spark job apocalypse panic - Axios

Description: Amazon CEO says layoffs aren't about AI, as cuts spark job apocalypse panicAxios Amazon says it didn‚Äôt cut 14,000 people because of money. It cut them because of ‚Äòculture‚ÄôCNN Amazon Employees In 'Constant Panic', Unable To Sleep Amid Layoff Threat, Viral Post‚Ä¶

Title: How Amazon flipped the script on a challenging week
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-layoffs-earnings-investors-happy-ai-progress-culture-2025-11
Time Published: 2025-11-01T09:24:02Z
Full Content:
Every time Eugene publishes a story, you‚Äôll get an alert straight to your inbox! Enter your email By clicking ‚ÄúSign up‚Äù, you agree to receive emails from Business Insider. In addition, you accept Insider‚Äôs Terms of Service and Privacy Policy. Tuesday brought 14,000 job cuts and fresh AI concerns. By Thursday, investors were cheering. It was a turbulent week for Amazon and its CEO Andy Jassy, marked by historic layoffs and rising doubts about AI, followed by a swift 48-hour rebound that reassured investors. Wall Street is impressed ‚Äî Amazon shares hit record highs on Friday ‚Äî though questions remain. "Amazon isn't perfect, and we are seeing increasing urgency in defending their cloud leadership position and reclaiming some of the unique culture," Baird's senior analyst Colin Sebastian told Business Insider. "Jassy's strategy is proving successful, even if there are still some wrinkles to work out." Tuesday's layoffs fueled concerns about Amazon's AI prowess, sparking questions over whether the cuts reflected slowing growth or that efficiency gains were paying off. The company said it was a preemptive move that makes it "leaner." Even before the layoffs, Amazon was contending with a widening perception that it was trailing in AI, with a top Wall Street analyst calling it an "AI laggard." On top of that, Amazon's yearlong push to streamline its culture and cut bureaucracy had yet to deliver stronger shareholder returns. Jassy has cut the manager-to-employee ratio by 15% this year as part of a broader push to instill discipline and reshape Amazon's culture. Until earlier this week, it was the only one of the seven largest tech firms to underperform the broader market over the past five years. Investors were especially worried about Amazon Web Services' slow growth, the company's high-margin cloud unit. Though it maintains a far larger revenue base, AWS' growth has lagged behind competitors such as Microsoft and Google. "AWS revenue growth acceleration is a must," CFRA wrote in a research note last week. Amazon put those concerns to rest on Thursday. The company's third-quarter earnings topped expectations, and it raised its capital spending forecast amid surging demand. AWS reported $33 billion in sales, a 20% increase, its fastest growth since 2022. The company also made a number of disclosures that showcased its progress in AI, including: Wall Street loved what it saw. "The AWS unlock is here," wrote Evercore's Mark Mahaney. Financial firm William Blair called it "a key step in reclaiming the narrative," while Barclays wrote in a note that "the past 48 hours have gone a long way to dispelling concerns." "AWS is gaining momentum," Jassy said during Thursday's earnings call. Still, skepticism remains. AWS may have pioneered the cloud, but the rise of AI is reshaping the landscape and giving rivals fresh ways to compete. Some of its flagship AI products have failed to gain much traction. And it didn't help that Jassy sidestepped an analyst's question on Thursday to specify how much of AWS' growth came from AI versus its core infrastructure business. DA Davidson's Gil Luria, who remains bullish on Amazon, told Business Insider that AWS still hasn't matched Microsoft or Google Cloud's lead in AI mindshare, and has plenty of catching up to do. "Amazon has been the slowest of the three hyperscalers in commercializing AI," Luria said. There's also uncertainty about whether the layoffs are over. Jassy said Thursday that the latest cuts weren't driven by cost pressures or AI, but by cultural alignment, implying the shake-up isn't done. "It's important to be lean, it's important to be flat, and it's important to move fast, and that's what we're going to do," Jassy said. Have a tip? Contact this reporter via email at ekim@businessinsider.com or Signal, Telegram, or WhatsApp at 650-942-3061. Title: CEO Andy Jassy says Amazon‚Äôs 14,000 layoffs weren‚Äôt about cutting costs or AI taking jobs: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs culture‚Äô
URL: https://fortune.com/2025/11/01/ceo-andy-jassy-amazon-layoffs-about-culture-not-ai/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T09:03:00Z
Full Content:
Role: ReporterMarco Quiroz-Gutierrez is a reporter for Fortune covering general business news. Amazon‚Äôs CEO has finally spoken up about the company‚Äôs 14,000 layoffs earlier this week, and he claims the motive was not at all financial. Speaking during the company‚Äôs quarterly earnings call Thursday, CEO Andy Jassy said laying off those employees was about a mismatched cultural fit‚Äîand nothing else. ‚ÄúThe announcement that we made a few days ago was not really financially driven, and it‚Äôs not even really AI-driven, not right now at least,‚Äù he said about the job cuts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs culture.‚Äù The job cuts this week, which mostly affected middle managers, follow a June memo in which Jassy said Amazon will need fewer employees thanks to the ‚Äúefficiency gains‚Äù brought on by AI. In a separate memo announcing this week‚Äôs layoffs, Amazon‚Äôs senior vice president of people said the layoffs were about adapting to ‚Äútransformative technology.‚Äù Jassy also mentioned Amazon‚Äôs business has grown over the past years. The company has about 1.55 million total employees, with 350,000 corporate employees alone. As of December 2019, prior to the pandemic, the company had 798,000 total employees, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ‚ÄúIf you grow as fast as we did for several years, the size of businesses, the number of people, the number of locations, the types of businesses you‚Äôre in, you end up with a lot more people than what you had before, and you end up with a lot more layers,‚Äù he said. This type of growth can lead to consequences, Jassy added. ‚ÄúSometimes without realizing it, you can weaken the ownership of the people that you have who are doing the actual work and who own most of the two-way door decisions, the ones that should be made quickly and right at the front line,‚Äù he said. A spokesperson for Amazon declined to comment. Amazon joins other companies such as Salesforce, Target, and Paramount who have together laid off thousands of workers in the past few months. Several large companies have cited AI as a reason for hiring pauses or layoffs recently, said Fed Chairman Jerome Powell this week, adding that the Fed is ‚Äúwatching that very carefully.‚Äù To be sure, a study of Goldman Sachs investment bankers this week found only 11% of their corporate clients were actively laying people off due to AI. In contrast, about a third of companies in the technology, media, and telecommunications category are reducing headcount because of AI. During the quarterly earnings call, Jassy seemed to echo the sentiment, saying the ‚Äútechnological transformation‚Äù currently underway means companies need to be nimble and adaptable. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to be lean, it‚Äôs important to be flat, and it‚Äôs important to move fast,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what we‚Äôre going to do.‚Äù ¬© 2025 Fortune Media IP Limited. All Rights Reserved. Title: The job market may be sinking. Why you should beware of buyouts.
URL: https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2025/11/01/layoffs-buyouts-job-market-employment/86984517007/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T09:01:35Z
Full Content:
You‚Äôve been offered a buyout. Your employer wants to pay you to quit. It‚Äôs a big chunk of change. But leaving your job now would mean searching for a new one in a weakening job market. Should you accept the offer? Companies offer buyouts to thin the ranks, spending money in the short term to save money in the long run. Employers often leverage buyouts to avoid layoffs in a shaky economy. And that thought, alone, should give you pause. The Trump administration offered buyouts to the entire federal workforce this year, aiming to reduce it by as much as 10%. Roughly 75,000 workers accepted. More recently, Amazon, UPS and Target all announced private-sector layoffs. Buyouts can sound tempting. A five-figure severance package might be the most money a worker has ever seen in one paycheck. But it‚Äôs also the last paycheck your employer will give you. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like lottery winners. Some people think the money lasts longer than it does,‚Äù said Donna Walton, wealth strategist at TD Wealth. If you are mulling a buyout, some considerations are universal: How large is the severance package? Am I close to retirement? Did I want to leave that job anyway? But the current economic climate presents its own challenges. Employers added only 22,000 jobs in August, according to the latest federal report. Unemployment ticked up to 4.3%, its highest level since October 2021. Nearly 2 million Americans have been out of work for six months or longer, the Labor Department reported in May, the largest number in more than two years. Companies are doing less hiring out of uncertainty about President Trump‚Äôs tariffs. Artificial intelligence is swiping jobs from new graduates. Recession fears loom. ‚ÄúIt is a very soft job market,‚Äù said Michele Evermore, a senior fellow at the National Academy of Social Insurance, and a former Labor Department official in the Biden Administration, speaking to USA TODAY earlier this year. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a period of economic uncertainty, I think people are hanging onto their jobs.‚Äù Here are five tips for employees who are thinking about taking buyouts in 2025. Let‚Äôs start with a proactive step. Maybe your employer hasn‚Äôt offered a buyout. But you‚Äôre restless to make a change, and you‚Äôve heard your company wants to cut costs. Consider approaching your managers and asking for a buyout. In many cases, there‚Äôs nothing to stop an employer from creating a voluntary severance package just for you. ‚ÄúYou do see these things happen, particularly if there‚Äôs news that a company is planning on downsizing,‚Äù said Michael Scarpati, CEO of RetireUS, a financial wellness platform. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of a win-win for both parties.‚Äù If you‚Äôre the first to ask for a buyout, you may get a better severance package than the one your employer eventually offers everyone else. But don‚Äôt ask for a buyout if you aren‚Äôt ready to take one. ‚ÄúYou have to be willing to leave if they do offer it to you,‚Äù Walton said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not something you want to bluff about.‚Äù A typical buyout might offer four weeks of pay, plus another week for every year you‚Äôve worked at the company. You might get extra health insurance coverage, even help in finding a new job. Roughly half of workers accept buyout offers without negotiating, AARP reports. But it can‚Äôt hurt to ask for better terms. ‚ÄúThink of it as if you‚Äôre going in for a job interview,‚Äù Scarpati said. You could ask for a full year of severance pay, rather than a few months. Perhaps your employer will cover the costs of health insurance while you look for a new job. Some workers hire attorneys to negotiate buyouts, said David John, a senior strategic policy adviser at the AARP Public Policy Institute. That might sound extreme, but remember: A buyout is a business proposition. The contracts can be complicated, sometimes including non-disclosure agreements or non-compete clauses. Even if you don‚Äôt bring a lawyer to a buyout negotiation, Walton said, ‚Äúyou should at least meet with one.‚Äù Unless you‚Äôre planning to retire, experts say, you should gauge your chances of finding another job before you leave your current job. If you work in a shrinking field, or in an economically afflicted region, you may already know it. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pretty different thing to take a buyout in D.C. if you work in a thinktank, or to take a buyout if you work on an oil rig in South Dakota,‚Äù Evermore said. Look at Labor Department jobs reports, Evermore said, to find out how many people are applying for unemployment insurance in your area, and how many are lingering on the benefit rolls. Better still: Apply for some jobs. See if you get bites. If not, that might be a good sign a buyout isn‚Äôt for you. In the best-case scenario, you can line up a new job before you take the buyout. Many employers offer buyouts to avoid layoffs, or at least to delay them. If you have a buyout offer, weigh the odds that the company will resort to layoffs once the buyouts are past. ‚ÄúA responsible company will address those worries right off the bat, and say yes or no,‚Äù said John of AARP. If layoffs are likely, think about whether you might land on a layoff list. Ask your manager if you are vulnerable. If your company has endured layoffs in the past, look at the severance packages those workers received. In some cases, Walton said, a buyout package might be ‚Äúthe same thing your company offers you if it lays you off six months from now.‚Äù Many federal workers who took buyouts from the Trump administration had only weeks to decide. That‚Äôs not nearly long enough, experts say. ‚ÄúAsking someone to make a major life decision that may involve relocating your whole family, you should get at least a few months for that,‚Äù Evermore said. Ideally, Scarpati said, six weeks is a ‚Äúminimum‚Äù timeframe for a buyout offer. Ninety days is more reasonable. Use that time to ‚Äúthink about where you‚Äôre at in your career,‚Äù Evermore said. Talk to friends, colleagues and loved ones about your options. Test the job market. Ask yourself if you‚Äôre ready to uproot your household and move across the country. And run the numbers. If you are mid-career, do you have enough emergency savings to survive a period of joblessness? How would you cover health insurance? How generous are the unemployment benefits in your state? If you are near retirement: When were you planning to take Social Security? How would you cover health insurance until Medicare kicks in? Do you have enough retirement savings? Consider meeting with a financial planner. ‚ÄúIdeally,‚Äù Walton said, ‚Äúhave this financial plan done before any of this happens.‚Äù
--------------------------------------------------

Title: U.S. Health Insurers Face Headwinds as Q3 Earnings Reveal Mounting Cost Pressures
URL: https://www.edgen.tech/news/stock/us-health-insurers-face-headwinds-as-q3-earnings-reveal-mounting-cost-pressures
Time Published: 2025-11-01T09:01:14Z
Full Content:
U.S. health insurers experienced a challenging third quarter, reporting increased medical costs and significant policy-related pressures, which led to a notable decline in share prices across the sector. U.S. health insurance companies encountered substantial financial headwinds in the third quarter, reporting results marked by escalating medical costs and the looming impact of legislative changes. The sector's performance lagged the broader market, with several major players experiencing significant stock price depreciation. The third-quarter earnings season, which commenced on October 21, unveiled a consistent theme of increased cost pressures across the health insurance industry. A primary driver of these rising expenses has been the government-subsidized Medicaid and Medicare Advantage plans, where UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH), the nation's largest insurer, specifically highlighted heightened acuity levels among its Medicaid enrollees following the resumption of state-led procedural disenrollment in March 2023. Centene Corporation (NYSE: CNC) reported a substantial $6.6 billion third-quarter loss, a stark contrast to its $713 million profit in the same period last year. This loss was largely attributed to escalating healthcare costs and a $6.7 billion non-cash goodwill impairment. The impairment was a consequence of a sustained decline in Centene's stock price throughout 2025 and the anticipated financial repercussions of the "One Big Beautiful Bill," which forecasts $1 trillion in cuts to Medicaid and Affordable Care Act (ACA) subsidies over the next decade. Centene's health benefits ratio (HBR), the proportion of premiums spent on medical care, climbed to 92.7%, up from 89.2% a year prior, underscoring the rising cost burden. Market reactions to these results were swift and negative. Since October 20, Elevance Health Inc. (ELV) shares fell 9.1%, UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH) declined 5.4%, and The Cigna Group (CI) dropped 19.5%. The most pronounced decrease among major managed care insurers was recorded by Molina Healthcare, Inc. (MOH), which saw its stock price decrease by 23.5%. These declines surpassed those of the broader market, with the S&P 500 falling 2.47% and the S&P Insurance Index decreasing 2.15% over the same period. The adverse market reaction reflects investor concerns over several interconnected factors. Primarily, the rising medical expense ratios indicate a squeeze on profitability, particularly as insurers grapple with sicker patient populations in government-funded programs. The "One Big Beautiful Bill" has introduced significant political uncertainty and financial risk, with projections suggesting it could eliminate health coverage for nearly 12 million Americans. This directly impacts insurers like Centene, which manage Medicaid plans for over 12 million low-income individuals. Furthermore, issues are not confined solely to Medicaid. UnitedHealth also noted the expected impact of changes within the ACA markets. The company anticipates that rate increases exceeding 25% and targeted service area reductions could lead to a decrease of approximately two-thirds in its Obamacare customer base, potentially forcing over one million enrollees to seek alternative coverage. These aggressive actions, while aimed at improving margins in the employer and individual segment by 2026, suggest ongoing struggles to achieve targeted profitability levels. The sector's performance in the third quarter highlights a challenging operating environment exacerbated by both fundamental cost pressures and a shifting regulatory landscape. The substantial goodwill impairment reported by Centene underscores the market's re-evaluation of long-term prospects in light of evolving healthcare policy. The company's valuation review specifically cited the expected financial impact of the "One Big Beautiful Bill" as a key factor. The broader market implications are significant. As insurers face increased costs and legislative changes that could reduce their customer base and subsidies, the sustainability of current business models, particularly within government-sponsored programs, comes into question. The aggressive rate hikes by UnitedHealthcare in the ACA marketplace indicate an industry-wide effort to adapt to these new realities, potentially at the expense of market share. While specific analyst quotes were not provided in the briefing, the collective sentiment from company executives and market movements suggests a cautious outlook. UnitedHealthcare chief executive Tim Noel indicated that the company's submitted rate filings reflect the 2025 morbidity and experience, including average rate increases of over 25%, as a necessary measure to improve margins. The acknowledgment that these margins are still projected to remain below the targeted 7‚Äì9% range for 2026 further underscores the persistent challenges. Investors will closely monitor several key factors in the coming quarters. The full implementation and impact of the "One Big Beautiful Bill" and its projected cuts to Medicaid and ACA subsidies will be a critical determinant for sector profitability. The ability of insurers to manage medical costs effectively, particularly within Medicaid and Medicare Advantage, will remain paramount. Furthermore, the strategies employed by major players like UnitedHealthcare to navigate the ACA landscape, including the potential for significant enrollee shifts, will provide insights into the sector's adaptability. The interplay of legislative policy, evolving patient demographics, and cost containment efforts will define the trajectory for U.S. health insurers in the near to medium term. ## First Majestic Silver (TSX:AG) Records Strong Performance **First Majestic Silver (TSX:AG)** has demonstrated robust stock performance, with shares advancing 7% over the past month. This recent movement contributes to a substantial 68% share price return over the last 90 days, underscoring a strong upward trend for the silver producer. The company's year-to-date gain currently stands above 110%, significantly outpacing broader market indices. This rally has notably impacted investor confidence and the company's overall valuation. ## Drivers of Recent Appreciation The sustained upward trajectory of **First Majestic Silver's** stock is primarily attributed to two key factors: a notable increase in global silver prices and a broader shift towards bullish sentiment within the mining sector. Rising commodity prices generally translate to improved revenue prospects for mining companies, directly benefiting silver producers like First Majestic. This positive market environment has fostered increased investor interest, signaling an optimistic outlook for the precious metals industry. The company's performance reflects a positive correlation between silver's market value and investor perception of mining sector profitability. ## Broader Market Context and Bullish Indicators **First Majestic Silver's** rally occurs within a period where certain market segments are exhibiting strong upward momentum. While distinct from other sectors, its performance contributes to a broader narrative of specific stocks achieving significant gains. For instance, recent market activity has seen several companies, including those outside the precious metals sector like **Comstock Resources (CRK)** and **Currenc (CURR)**, demonstrate substantial returns. **Comstock Resources (CRK)**, for example, recorded a 68% total return over the last year, despite recent volatility. Similarly, **Currenc (CURR)** experienced a 75% cumulative gain over a five-day streak, achieving a 110% year-to-date return. These examples, though in different industries, illustrate a market environment where strong company-specific catalysts or sector-wide tailwinds can lead to considerable stock appreciation, often viewed as bullish indicators by traders and investors. This generalized positive momentum suggests an appetite for growth opportunities among market participants. ## Valuation Considerations and Future Outlook The significant price appreciation of **First Majestic Silver** inevitably brings its valuation into focus. While specific valuation ratios were not detailed, the substantial gains across monthly, quarterly, and year-to-date periods suggest investors are pricing in continued growth and profitability. The positive impact of rising silver prices and increased investor confidence could sustain this momentum. Looking ahead, the performance of **First Majestic Silver** will likely remain sensitive to fluctuations in global silver demand and supply, macroeconomic trends influencing commodity prices, and the overall sentiment towards precious metals. Continued geopolitical stability or instability, and their implications for safe-haven assets, will also be crucial factors for monitoring the company's trajectory. ## Opening: Stryker's Mixed Financial Signals **Stryker Corporation (SYK)**, a leading medical technology firm, presented a complex financial picture in its third-quarter 2025 earnings report. While the company exceeded analyst expectations for sales and adjusted earnings, prompting a raised full-year guidance, its reported net profit margins experienced a notable contraction. This dip was largely attributed to a significant one-off $1.4 billion loss, introducing a challenging element to an otherwise robust operational performance. ## The Quarter in Detail: Exceeding Operational Forecasts For the third quarter ended September 30, 2025, **Stryker** reported net sales of $6.1 billion, marking a substantial 10.3% increase compared to the prior year. Adjusted earnings per share (EPS) grew by 11.1% to $3.19, surpassing consensus estimates by nearly $0.03 per share. The company's adjusted operating income margin improved by 90 basis points to 25.6%, reflecting underlying operational efficiencies and business mix. However, the reported net profit for the quarter stood at $859 million, or $2.22 per share. This figure was significantly impacted by a one-off $1.4 billion loss, leading to a reported net profit margin of 12.1%, a decrease from 16.3% in the previous year. Despite this, **Stryker** demonstrated strong organic sales growth of 9.5%, driven by high demand across its diverse business segments, including MedSurg, Neurotechnology, and Orthopedics. ## Market Reaction and Underlying Dynamics Despite beating consensus Wall Street forecasts for both sales and adjusted earnings, **Stryker (SYK)** shares experienced a slight dip following the announcement. This muted market reaction can be understood in the context of the reported net margin compression and existing valuation concerns. While the adjusted operational performance signals underlying strength, the one-off loss likely overshadowed these positives, causing investors to scrutinize the headline net profit figures. The improvement in adjusted gross margin, up 50 basis points to 65% over Q3 2024, indicates successful cost optimization and supply chain management, partially offsetting external headwinds such as tariffs. However, the divergence between strong adjusted metrics and a lower reported net profit margin highlights the sensitivity of investor sentiment to one-time events. ## Broader Context, Valuation, and Headwinds **Stryker's** performance contrasts with broader market expectations in several areas. Analysts project annual earnings growth for **Stryker** at 17.3%, outpacing the broader U.S. market's 15.9%. However, its projected revenue growth of 7.7% annually lags the U.S. market's 10.3% rate. A notable concern for investors is **Stryker's** valuation; the stock trades at a price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 46.3x, which is significantly higher than its industry average and peer group. This premium valuation suggests that investors are paying a hefty price for future growth, increasing the downside risk if expectations are not met. The company has faced several challenges impacting its margins, including an estimated $200 million net impact from tariffs for the full year 2025, ongoing supply chain disruptions, particularly in emergency care, and higher interest expenses due to recent debt issuances. These factors underscore the operational complexities in the current economic environment, even for a market leader like **Stryker**. ## Looking Ahead: Sustained Growth Trajectory with Cautious Optimism Building on its robust Q3 performance and strong demand, **Stryker** has raised its full-year 2025 guidance. The company now anticipates organic net sales growth to be in the range of 9.8% to 10.2% and adjusted earnings per share between $13.50 and $13.60. This upward revision reflects management's confidence in continued operational momentum and successful product innovations, such as the Mako 4 and LifePak 35 launches. Despite this optimistic outlook, market observers will closely monitor **Stryker's** ability to sustain its adjusted margin expansion amidst persistent tariff pressures, potential regulatory delays, and ongoing supply chain challenges. The high valuation necessitates a consistent delivery of strong results to justify the premium, making future earnings reports critical for reinforcing investor confidence and ensuring a sustained bullish narrative for the stock. ## The Event in Detail **Black Rock Coffee Bar, Inc.** (Nasdaq: **BRCB**) has scheduled a conference call to discuss its financial results for the third quarter of 2025. The event is set to take place on Tuesday, November 11th, 2025, at 5:00 p.m. Eastern Time. Domestic participants can access the live conference call by dialing 1-877-704-4453. International callers may join by dialing 1-201-389-0920. For those preferring digital access, a live webcast of the proceedings will be available through the investor relations section of **Black Rock Coffee Bar**'s official website, accessible at ir.br.coffee. For investors unable to attend the live call, a replay will be made available approximately two hours after its conclusion. The replay will remain accessible until November 25th, 2025. Domestic callers can access the replay at 1-844-512-2921, while international participants can dial 1-412-317-6671. The required passcode for accessing the replay is 13756076. ## Context and Implications The announcement of an earnings conference call is a standard practice for publicly traded companies like **Black Rock Coffee Bar**, serving as a critical touchpoint for transparency and investor relations. These calls offer a direct channel for management to communicate financial performance, operational highlights, and strategic direction to the market. For **BRCB**, this upcoming call provides an opportunity for investors to assess the company's financial health and growth trajectory within the competitive specialty coffee market. Key metrics such as revenue growth, profitability, same-store sales, and expansion initiatives will be closely scrutinized. The current market sentiment surrounding this announcement is neutral, as is typical before the release of actual financial data, with anticipation building for the details to be presented. ## Looking Ahead As the date approaches, analysts and investors will be particularly keen to hear management's commentary on several fronts. This includes insights into current market conditions affecting the coffee industry, updates on **Black Rock Coffee Bar**'s store expansion plans, and any forward-looking guidance on revenue or earnings targets. Any discussions regarding supply chain management, commodity costs, or consumer spending patterns will also draw significant attention. Furthermore, the call is expected to shed light on **BRCB**'s strategies for enhancing customer loyalty and driving operational efficiencies. The insights provided during this conference call will be crucial for market participants in calibrating their valuations and expectations for the company's performance in the short to medium term. The information shared could influence stock performance following the release of the third-quarter results.

URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/markets/stocks/news/wall-st-week-ahead-resilient-stocks-rally-faces-earnings-wave-after-ai-fed-wobbles/articleshow/125009503.cms

Indian markets are watching a strong US stock rally. Investors are focused on upcoming company earnings and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The market is at high valuations, making earnings crucial for future gains. The first week of November is historically positive for stocks. AI investments are a key theme, with companies announcing spending and investors seeking returns. Title: The AI-Driven Stock Runup May Not Be As Good As Many Assume
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/eriksherman/2025/10/31/the-ai-driven-stock-runup-may-not-be-as-good-as-many-assume/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T03:37:06Z
Full Content:
ByErik Sherman, Senior Contributor. The witching hour. Is this about All Hallow‚Äôs Eve? No, it‚Äôs about tech companies ‚Äî AI-focused in particular. Promise, hype, and intra-sector cross-investment has created an interesting dynamic of economic concentration and risk. By no means is this to say that tech companies and their stocks are bad. It also isn‚Äôt to say they will be good at all times and past performance is a guarantee of future returns. Technology stocks have shown strong returns, as they have in 2023 and 2024, according to U.S. Bank. The information technology sector gained 23% year-to-date on October 21, 2025. The tech-focused communication services sector gained 25%. In contrast, the S&P 500 increased by 15% and the return for the Nasdaq composite was 19%. More specifically, the so-called Magnificent Seven ‚Äî Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia, and Tesla ‚Äî comprise 36.6% of the S&P 500 as of October 2025, up from 12.3% in 2015, according to The Motley Fool. In year-to-date performance, the Magnificent Seven had returns of 18.6% compared to 14.5% of the S&P 500. A big reason is due to artificial intelligence growth. Stanford University‚Äôs Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence group calculated that corporate AI investment reached $252.3 billion in 2024. Year-over-year private investment was up 44.5% and mergers and acquisitions, up 12.1%. The current AI and tech success, though, creates some structural issues. ‚ÄúThe S&P 500 is built on a ‚Äòsurvivor bias‚Äô basis, with companies having the most success making up the largest weightings,‚Äù Vince Stanzione, former currency trader and CEO of financial publisher First Information, says. The higher the market capitalization of the company, the higher its standing in the S&P 500. Stanzione compared two S&P 500-related exchange-traded funds: the Invesco S&P 500 Equal Weight EFT (RSP) and SPDR S&P 500 (SPY). ‚ÄúIf you compare the equal-weighted RSP to SPY, you will see the equal-weighted is doing poorly, only up around 8% [year-to-date] compared to 17%.‚Äù The reason SPY did better is that it includes larger shares of top technology stocks. ‚ÄúIt is somewhat worrying to have such high exposure in the S&P 500, and at some stage the sector will correct,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúFor my own trading and clients, we have also had large exposure to mining stocks ‚Äî which are hardly represented in the SPY ‚Äî and, even after the recent pullback, this is up 113% YTD and on a far lower [price-earnings ratio] multiple than tech stocks, so there are still opportunities in other sectors. But for those just passively tracking the S&P 500, they remain tech-heavy and will keep dancing until the music stops.‚Äù The market excitement over AI is fueled by investor belief on its future. But the concentration of tech acts in a way like leverage in investing. The expectations can pile on atop the other. An example The Motley Fool gave was Nvidia. Since the end of 2015, the company has added trillions to its market cap, moving from the smallest contributor to the Magnificent Seven to the largest. That was a jump from 0.8% of the combined value to the largest at 21.2%. If you have ever seen a juggler balancing a spinning plate on a pole, then you know the plates must keep rotating to maintain their stability. ‚ÄúThe current market continues to consolidate with outperformance limited to fewer and fewer stocks, mostly based on the promise of AI and, perhaps more compelling, spending on AI infrastructure,‚Äù says Geoff Strotman of investment consulting firm Segal Marco Advisors. ‚ÄúMany of these stocks happen to be the largest stocks in the US stock market (and the largest in history), which is quickly driving performance and valuations higher.‚Äù Strotman notes that while the S&P 500 is at ‚Äúhistorically high valuation,‚Äù there are many other areas of the global stock market ‚Äî US small caps and non-US stocks ‚Äî that remain at average valuations. That can mean good returns with lower investment amounts. He adds that emerging markets are having a strong year, up almost 30% year-to-date. ‚ÄúThe emerging markets outperformance is also a reminder for institutional investors to remain diversified and rebalance into underperforming asset classes in order to take advantage of return divergence and opportunities as Emerging Markets was just about left for dead at the beginning of the year,‚Äù Strotman says. However, concerns about risk from tech, or any other type of stock type, can create its own problems. ‚ÄúThe debate over whether AI is a 'boom' or a 'bubble' is interesting, but in reality, it‚Äôs a distraction to everyday investors focused on long-term wealth,‚Äù says Alex Michalka, head of investments at Weatlthfront. ‚ÄúNo one can know the answer for sure, and attempting to adjust your strategy based on a guess is a form of market timing, which historically is not a wise approach. Instead, you‚Äôre better off focusing on ensuring you have a well-diversified portfolio that includes the level of risk you‚Äôre comfortable with based on your situation and time horizon.‚Äù In other words, if technology is an area where you find heightened risk, you don‚Äôt need to run away from it. A diversified portfolio is an intelligent investment tool. Michalka mentioned direct indexing, in which you buy individual stocks to imitate an existing stock index like the S&P 500 or Nasdaq. You can look for areas of tech that gives some of the upside without being married to it.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Texas And New York Set To Send Contrasting Signals To Investors
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/patrickgleason/2025/10/31/texas-and-new-york-set-to-send-contrasting-signals-to-investors/
Time Published: 2025-11-01T03:30:15Z
Full Content:
ByPatrick Gleason, Contributor. Next Tuesday, November 5, New York City voters are likely to elect a new mayor who has campaigned on income tax hikes for upper-income households and businesses. Meanwhile, that same day, Texas voters are expected to approve ballot measures banning state taxation of capital gains and the imposition of a financial transactions tax. The heightened contrast is sure to help the Texas Stock Exchange (TXSE), the new Dallas-based stock market set to launch in 2026. An October 31 Wall Street Journal report about a new $90 million commitment to the TXSE from J.P. Morgan, the investment bank of JPMorgan Chase, noted that the TXSE ‚Äúhas billed itself as more CEO-friendly‚Äù than the New York Stock Exchange, adding that ‚Äúprevious investors include Citadel Securities, BlackRock and Charles Schwab.‚Äù The new infusion from JP Morgan, the WSJ added, ‚Äúbrings TXSE‚Äôs total fundraising to date above $250 million.‚Äù Ballot propositions banning a state death tax, a financial transactions tax, and a capital gains tax aren‚Äôt the only 2025 ballot measures that are set to make Texas an even more attractive destination to live, work, and invest. Texas voters will have the opportunity to enact reforms that provide further tax cuts, particularly property tax relief. Polling shows Texas voters are likely to approve Proposition 13, which will provide property tax relief to Lone Star State residents through a 40% increase in the homestead exemption. The state‚Äôs $100,000 homestead exemption would rise to $140,000 if voters enact Proposition 13 next Tuesday. ‚ÄúWhile not a permanent fix to property taxes, the amendment should help slow the growth of property taxes for all homeowners,‚Äù says Texans for Fiscal Responsibility (TFR), who has endorsed Proposition 13. While Proposition 13 seeks to provide relief for all property taxpayers in Texas, Proposition 9 would provide relief from the business personal property tax, commonly referred to as the inventory tax, to small businesses across the state. If approved, Proposition 9 would significantly increase the existing $2,500 inventory tax exemption, raising it to $125,000. ‚ÄúTexas is one of just nine states where small business owners pay taxes on the value of their inventory for sale, their personal property, and everything else used to generate income,‚Äù noted the National Federation of Independent Business‚Äôs Texas chapter in its statement of support for Proposition 9. NFIB adds that passage of Proposition 9 ‚Äúwould save Texas small businesses over $500 million annually,‚Äù and ‚Äúmake Texas even more competitive amongst its neighboring states.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis constitutional amendment simplifies compliance, reduces bureaucratic costs, and incentivizes productivity,‚Äù notes TFR‚Äôs analysis of Proposition 9. ‚ÄúIt cuts down on burdensome taxation that can stifle economic growth, especially for small operations. This is a pro-growth, pro-business reform that respects taxpayers and limits government overreach.‚Äù The ballot measures that Texas voters will likely approve on November 5 underscore why governors and legislative leaders in so many states are pursuing a phaseout of their income tax that would have them join Texas in the club of no-income-tax states. The eight existing no-income-tax states have already demonstrated the economic benefits of avoiding an income tax, and many are now seeking to expand that advantage by making their tax codes even more competitive. Texas isn‚Äôt the only no-income-tax state where legislators are pursuing property tax relief. In fact, in no-income-tax Florida, Governor Ron DeSantis is now pushing for a full phaseout of property taxes in Florida. In particular, Governor DeSantis is championing a single measure for the 2026 ballot that would begin phasing out all property taxes in Florida. Republicans in the Florida House of Representatives introduced eight property tax relief proposals on October 17, with seven of them being constitutional amendments requiring voter approval in November of 2026. Constitutional amendments must receive approval from at least 60% of voters in order to be enacted. The James Madison Institute, a Florida-based think tank, recently conducted a poll that found 65% of those surveyed said they would support a ballot measure to provide property tax relief. Lawmakers in other states are also pursuing property tax relief or limitation in the coming year. In no-income-tax Tennessee, for example, legislators will seek to pass a bill in 2026 that limits the growth of property tax bills. Tennessee is currently one of only four states without some form of property tax limit on the books. ‚ÄúTo provide relief for taxpayers, we must set firm limits on how fast local governments can grow their budgets,‚Äù Justin Owen, president of the Beacon Center of Tennessee, and John Hendrickson, policy director at Iowans for Tax Relief, wrote in an October 17 article in Governing Magazine. ‚ÄúThis will ensure that taxes do not outpace the ability of families and businesses to pay. Taxpayers must be protected from unchecked growth in local government spending.‚Äù ‚ÄúEliminating property taxes may be a noble solution, but tax policy should always be approached with prudence,‚Äù Owen and Hendrickson added. ‚ÄúReplacing property taxes with a new tax or raising an existing tax to a higher rate, or even shifting more responsibilities to the state budget, are not necessarily sound tax policies. The best approach to lower taxes is to limit local government spending.‚Äù There were already plenty of reasons for lawmakers in no-income-tax states to pursue property tax cuts, property tax limits, and other forms of tax relief. But the case for doing so is strengthened by the fact that, at present, governors and legislators in nearly a dozen states across the country are seeking to phase out their income taxes. As more states eliminate their income tax, the lack of a state income tax will become less of an advantage. Leaders of no-income-tax states ‚Äî such as Governors Abbott in Texas, DeSantis in Florida, and Lee in Tennessee ‚Äî have made clear they are not resting on their laurels and that they welcome the competition.
--------------------------------------------------

Title: Alphabet (GOOGL) Posts Q3 Earnings Beat; AI Helps Boost Search and Cloud Growth
URL: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/lphabet-googl-posts-q3-earnings-233845881.html

Title: US stock market ends the October on a strong note ‚Äî How did the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow perform? Here‚Äôs the top gainers and losers on Wall Street
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-stock-market-ends-the-october-on-a-strong-note-how-did-the-sp-500-nasdaq-and-dow-perform-heres-the-top-gainers-and-losers-on-wall-street/articleshow/125008358.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-01T01:54:42Z
Full Content:
US stock market today surged as Amazon shares jumped 9.6% after reporting Q3 revenue of $180.2 billion and 20% growth at AWS. The Nasdaq rose 0.61% to 23,724.96, the S&P 500 climbed 0.26% to 6,840.20, and the Dow added 40.75 points to 47,562.87. AI-linked names rallied with Palantir up 3% and Oracle up 2.2%. Netflix gained 2.7% on a 10-for-1 stock split and Tesla advanced 3.7%. October ended with the S&P 500 up 2.3%, Nasdaq +4.7% and the Dow +2.5%. Title: US stock market ends the October on a strong note ‚Äî How did the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow perform? Here‚Äôs the top gainers and losers on Wall Street
URL: https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/us/us-stock-market-ends-the-october-on-a-strong-note-how-did-the-sp-500-nasdaq-and-dow-perform-heres-the-top-gainers-and-losers-on-wall-street/articleshow/125008358.cms
Time Published: 2025-11-01T01:54:42Z
Full Content:
US stock market today surged as Amazon shares jumped 9.6% after reporting Q3 revenue of $180.2 billion and 20% growth at AWS. The Nasdaq rose 0.61% to 23,724.96, the S&P 500 climbed 0.26% to 6,840.20, and the Dow added 40.75 points to 47,562.87. AI-linked names rallied with Palantir up 3% and Oracle up 2.2%. Netflix gained 2.7% on a 10-for-1 stock split and Tesla advanced 3.7%. October ended with the S&P 500 up 2.3%, Nasdaq +4.7% and the Dow +2.5%. (Catch all the US News, UK News, Canada News, International Breaking News Events, and Latest News Updates on The Economic Times.) Download The Economic Times News App to get Daily International News Updates. (Catch all the US News, UK News, Canada News, International Breaking News Events, and Latest News Updates on The Economic Times.) Title: Does Bitcoin Power Law model still work in 2025 after S2F failed?
URL: https://cryptoslate.com/does-the-bitcoin-power-law-model-still-hold-after-stock-to-flow-failed/
Time Published: 2025-10-31T23:00:37Z
Full Content:
The range that matters: $48k floor to $492k top, with the top increasing over time. Cover art/illustration via CryptoSlate. Image includes combined content which may include AI-generated content. With S2F in the rearview, the live power-law channel indicates that BTC is roughly 20% below fair value, but ETF flows could push it to either extreme. Bitbo‚Äôs implementation of Giovanni Santostasi‚Äôs model places the price near $109,700, the fair value near $136,100, the support near $48,300, and the resistance near $491,800, which frames the current cycle within a rising corridor derived from a power-law fit to price over time. The channel is constructed by running a linear regression of log(price) versus log(time since genesis), then duplicating that line in parallel to form upper and lower bounds that have historically contained cyclical extremes. The result is a time-based compounding curve with rails that move upward as time passes, making the model more of a location map than a point forecast. The core claim is simple to evaluate in live markets. Bitcoin trades about 20 percent below the fair-value regression and more than twice above the model‚Äôs floor, a mid-zone placement that contrasts with prior cycle tops and bottoms when the price tagged the channel‚Äôs resistance or support. Parameterization used by BGeometrics expresses the fair-value curve as P ‚âà 1.0117√ó10^-17 √ó (days since genesis)^5.82, with a commonly referenced floor at about 0.42 times the curve, which is consistent with the present gap between spot price and Bitbo‚Äôs lower rail. The specification includes historical drawdowns while allowing for late-cycle overextensions toward the upper band. The logic behind this approach treats adoption as a power function of time and expects volatility to decay as the network matures, a property that appears as tightening oscillations around the regression line over successive cycles. Recent flows help explain why the price is in the channel‚Äôs middle rather than at an extreme. Crypto exchange-traded products (ETPs) drew a record $5.95 billion in net inflows during the week ending October 4, 2025, with Bitcoin reaching an all-time high of approximately $126,000, alongside strong demand for U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs. The following two weeks showed that flows are not a one-way input. CoinShares recorded a swing to $3.17 billion of net inflows, followed by a reversal to $513 million of net outflows, including a single-week Bitcoin outflow of $946 million. Over the last two days alone, $958 million has exited US Bitcoin ETFs, with $290 million leaving BlackRock on October 30. That cadence is consistent with the power-law framing, where transitory demand surges or air pockets push price toward the upper or lower rails over weeks, while the long-run trajectory is anchored to the time-based power curve. October highs were tied to the breakout wave of ETF subscriptions, which are now a visible macro lever for crypto demand. The forward question, therefore, is not whether the power-law structure still applies, but where within the channel Bitcoin will trade over the next leg. A base-case path keeps the price oscillating around the regression, currently near $136,100, with a dampened amplitude if the volatility decay property holds. A bull-case path would see continued ETF inflows and benign macro conditions pull the price toward the upper resistance, near $491,800 today, which prior cycles reached during late-stage runs. A bear-case scenario would arise from macro tightening, a regulatory shock, or persistent ETF outflows that drive a retest of the lower rail near $48,300. This level has historically seen capitulation wicks before reentry into the channel. These levels rise with time as the exponent on days since genesis compounds. The rails are directional guardrails, not fixed targets. For readers tracking levels at a glance, the live model ranges are: PlanB‚Äôs S2F path called for $98,000 by November 2021 and $135,000 by December 2021, targets that were not met. The price then spent years below the S2F trajectory, an out-of-sample failure that weakened confidence in using a univariate stock-to-flow ratio to set deterministic targets. Vitalik Buterin has criticized S2F for providing false precision, and many analysts have identified methodological issues, including overfitting, the omission of demand and liquidity variables, and the treatment of halvings as step-wise valuation shifts that do not account for market microstructure. Institutional researchers continue to caution that S2F is not a reliable tool for long-term pricing. That leaves S2F as a scarcity narrative rather than a forecasting model. Power-law adherents, by contrast, argue that the cycle length and amplitude can be bounded without hard-dating outcomes. CryptoSlate has previously outlined broad windows in which Bitcoin would not sustain prices below roughly six figures after 2028 and could, at some point between 2028 and 2037, touch the seven-figure mark. Those are ranges, not calendar calls, and they inherit the same caveats as any model that ignores policy shocks or structural changes in market access. The new structural change is ETF flow, which functions as a demand valve that can overpower the marginal issuance cuts that halvings encode. Sustained weekly spot inflows above $2 billion to $3 billion would raise the odds of an upper-band test, while persistent outflows would increase the probability of a regression or floor retest. Macro liquidity, including the path of rates, the dollar, and central bank balance sheets, still takes center stage in determining whether the price holds above the regression or drifts toward the lower rail. That macro overlay is absent in S2F and is only indirectly present in the power-law fit, which is why practitioners track flows and policy alongside the channel. The power-law channel is constructed by taking daily BTCUSD closes, transforming them to log(price) versus log(time since genesis), fitting a simple linear regression as the fair-value curve, and then copying that line up and down in parallel to form resistance and support that historically enclose the price. The elegance lies in its production of a monotonically rising, time-based framework with a visible margin of error, which, so far, has captured cycle extremes without claiming to know the date or magnitude of future blow-offs. The cost is that it does not mechanistically incorporate known drivers, such as ETF demand or liquidity cycles, which must be monitored to understand where within the channel price is likely to reside in the near term. For now, the live read is straightforward. Price sits about one-fifth below the regression, well above the floor, with ETF flows and macroeconomic conditions determining whether Bitcoin tags the upper band or fades toward support before reverting to the mean. The channel continues to rise with time, and the rails define the tradable map. Also known as "Akiba," Liam Wright is a reporter, podcast producer, and Editor-in-Chief at CryptoSlate. Time Published: 2025-10-31T21:10:00Z
Full Content:

(‚ÄúPurpose‚Äù) today announced changes to the risk ratings for certain funds that it manages. Risk Rating Changes Purpose has changed the risk ratings for the following funds, effective October 31, 2025: Each of these changes is a result of the standardized investment risk classification methodology mandated by the Canadian Securities Administrators and the periodic review by Purpose to determine the risk level of its publicly offered mutual funds. No material changes have been made to the investment objective, strategies, or management of these funds as a result. The changes in the risk ratings will be reflected in each fund‚Äôs offering documents, which will be completed in accordance with applicable securities laws. Purpose has an unrelenting focus on client-centric innovation and offers a range of managed and quantitative investment products. Purpose is led by well-known entrepreneur Som Seif and is a division of Purpose Unlimited, an independent technology-driven financial services company.
